message: Fix schema errors
description: The XML files within a wsp solution should not contain schema errors.

details.resolution: The XML of elements in a Solution should not contain schema errors. This can occur because of typos in XML files or violations against the XML schema of a SharePoint element. If there are schema errors the solution may not be deserialized by SharePoint or rules of SPCAF can not be applied.
details.remarks: The XML of elements in a Solution should not contain schema errors. This can occur because of typos in XML files or violations against the XML schema of a SharePoint element. If there are schema errors the solution may not be deserialized by SharePoint or rules of SPCAF can not be applied.

message: Declare required attribute 'SolutionId' in Solution
description: Required attribute 'SolutionId' must be declared in Solution.

details.resolution: Add required attribute 'SolutionId' to Solution. The solution schema definition at MSDN defines the attribute 'SolutionId' as optional value but SPCAF requires a valid solution id. If the SolutionId is not present the deployment process may fail or existing scripts for installation of the solutions are not working. See sample below (MSDN):
details.remarks: Add required attribute 'SolutionId' to Solution. The solution schema definition at MSDN defines the attribute 'SolutionId' as optional value but SPCAF requires a valid solution id. If the SolutionId is not present the deployment process may fail or existing scripts for installation of the solutions are not working. See sample below (MSDN):

message: Define a valid GUID for attribute 'SolutionId' in Solution
description: The attribute 'SolutionId' in Solution must be a valid GUID. Otherwise the deployment or retraction of the solution may not work properly.

details.resolution: Ensure that attribute 'SolutionId' in a Solution is a valid GUID. See sample below (MSDN):
details.remarks: Ensure that attribute 'SolutionId' in a Solution is a valid GUID. See sample below (MSDN):

message: Remove unused files from Solution package
description: Files in the solution package which are not listed in manifest.xml or in a feature.xml should be removed from the package.

details.resolution: Delete the file from the package or update the manifest.xml to include the file.
details.remarks: Delete the file from the package or update the manifest.xml to include the file.

details.remarks: Add element 'SafeControl' to manifest.xml for each WebControl (which is not abstract) in the assembly. See sample below:

message: Deploy referenced Assembly with correct version, culture and public key token
description: If an assembly references a different assembly then version, culture and public key token of the referenced assembly must be the same or use BindingRedirects.

details.resolution: Deploy the referenced Assembly with the correct version, culture and public key token or use BindingRedirects to map different versions of the assembly correctly.
details.remarks: Deploy the referenced Assembly with the correct version, culture and public key token or use BindingRedirects to map different versions of the assembly correctly.

message: Do not set SPSite.CatchAccessDeniedException property
description: Property SPSite.CatchAccessDeniedException is reserved for internal use. Use the SPSecurity.CatchAccessDeniedException property instead to specify whether SharePoint Foundation traps and handles "Access Denied" exceptions.

details.resolution: Use SPSecurity.CatchAccessDeniedException instead of using SPSite.CatchAccessDeniedException. Mircosoft warns to use members which are reserved for internal use only because your code could break in the next hotfix or service pack. See sample below: Bad Example:
details.remarks: Use SPSecurity.CatchAccessDeniedException instead of using SPSite.CatchAccessDeniedException. Mircosoft warns to use members which are reserved for internal use only because your code could break in the next hotfix or service pack. See sample below: Bad Example:

message: Do not set SPSite.ReadLocked property
description: Property SPSite.ReadLocked is reserved for internal and is not intended to be used directly from your code. Use the IsReadLocked property instead.

details.resolution: Use SPSite.IsReadLocked instead (for SP2013) or use the SPSiteAdministration.ReadLocked property of the SPSiteAdministration class (for SP2010) instead . Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Use SPSite.IsReadLocked instead (for SP2013) or use the SPSiteAdministration.ReadLocked property of the SPSiteAdministration class (for SP2010) instead . Bad Practice:

message: Remove spaces from Feature folder

message: Do not define attribute 'ActiveOnDefault' in Feature with Scope 'Web' or 'Site'
description: Attribute 'ActivateOnDefault' cannot be 'TRUE' for Feature with Scope 'Web' or 'Site', except in Sandboxed solutions. In Sandboxed solutions the attribute is used during activation of the solution to activate Feature with scope 'Site'. This behaviour is not documented in MSDN and may be unexpected und unintended.

details.resolution: Completely remove attribute 'ActivateOnDefault' from a Feature with Scope 'Web' or 'Site'.
details.remarks: Completely remove attribute 'ActivateOnDefault' from a Feature with Scope 'Web' or 'Site'.

details.remarks: Completely remove attribute 'AutoActivateInCentralAdmin' from a Feature with Scope 'Farm'.

message: Define Version in Feature correctly
description: Version in Feature should contain a correct version number.

details.resolution: Change current attribute 'Version' in Feature to a correct version number (e.g. Version="1.0.5.234"). If the version number is not correctly defined future feature upgrade actions may not run as exepected. Feature upgrade actions use the version number to run different operations depending on the version of the Feature.
details.remarks: Change current attribute 'Version' in Feature to a correct version number (e.g. Version="1.0.5.234"). If the version number is not correctly defined future feature upgrade actions may not run as exepected. Feature upgrade actions use the version number to run different operations depending on the version of the Feature.

details.remarks: Add missing Assembly to the WSP package or include the WSP with the Assembly in the analysis.

message: Deploy the 'ReceiverAssembly' of a Feature to GAC
description: If a Feature references an assembly in attribute 'ReceiverAssembly' the assembly must be deployed to GAC. Otherwise the assembly could not be loaded during feature activation.

details.resolution: Change the attribute 'DeploymentTargetType' of the assembly in solutions manifest.xml to 'GlobalAssemblyCache'. MSDN: 'The assembly that contains a Feature receiver must be located in the global assembly cache (GAC).'
details.remarks: Change the attribute 'DeploymentTargetType' of the assembly in solutions manifest.xml to 'GlobalAssemblyCache'. MSDN: 'The assembly that contains a Feature receiver must be located in the global assembly cache (GAC).'

message: Declare Scope for Receivers in Site Features
description: If event receivers are used within a feature with scope 'Site' the attribute 'Scope' should be specified.

details.resolution: The Receiver element should specify attribute 'Scope' with value 'Site' or 'Web'. See MSDN: 'When a SharePoint Feature is scoped to the site collection level, a 'Receivers' tag is potentially ambiguous. The tag can indicate either site-wide event binding or event binding for the top-level site. Note, however, that the default behavior is to scope to the site level. Therefore, when you scope a Feature to the site collection level, use the attribute named Scope to specify the intended scope. When you set this attribute to 'Site', event receivers that are defined inside a Feature that is scoped to the site collection are then bound at the site collection level. When the attribute is set to 'Web', event receivers that are defined for a Feature of a site collection are bound at the root Web site of that site collection.'. See sample below:
details.remarks: The Receiver element should specify attribute 'Scope' with value 'Site' or 'Web'. See MSDN: 'When a SharePoint Feature is scoped to the site collection level, a 'Receivers' tag is potentially ambiguous. The tag can indicate either site-wide event binding or event binding for the top-level site. Note, however, that the default behavior is to scope to the site level. Therefore, when you scope a Feature to the site collection level, use the attribute named Scope to specify the intended scope. When you set this attribute to 'Site', event receivers that are defined inside a Feature that is scoped to the site collection are then bound at the site collection level. When the attribute is set to 'Web', event receivers that are defined for a Feature of a site collection are bound at the root Web site of that site collection.'. See sample below:

message: Do not add ActivationDependency to hidden Feature
description: Features with ActivationDependency cannot be hidden.

details.resolution: Change the attribute 'Hidden' to 'False' in each Feature with an ActivationDependency. MSDN: 'You can target an activation dependency against hidden or visible Features, but hidden Features cannot have activation dependencies. The Hidden attribute on the Feature element determines whether the Feature is displayed in the user interface.'
details.remarks: Change the attribute 'Hidden' to 'False' in each Feature with an ActivationDependency. MSDN: 'You can target an activation dependency against hidden or visible Features, but hidden Features cannot have activation dependencies. The Hidden attribute on the Feature element determines whether the Feature is displayed in the user interface.'

message: Do not add ActivationDependency to a Feature with a more restrictive scope
description: A Feature cannot have an ActivationDependency to a more restrictive scope. For example, a site collection-scoped Feature cannot have an ActivationDependency on a Web site-scoped Feature.

details.resolution: Remove the ActivationDependency or change the scope of the target Feature. MSDN: 'Cross-scope activation dependencies are not supported if the Feature depended upon is at a more restrictive scope. For example, a site collection-scoped Feature cannot have an activation dependency on a Web site–scoped Feature.'
details.remarks: Remove the ActivationDependency or change the scope of the target Feature. MSDN: 'Cross-scope activation dependencies are not supported if the Feature depended upon is at a more restrictive scope. For example, a site collection-scoped Feature cannot have an activation dependency on a Web site–scoped Feature.'

message: Do not add cross-scope ActivationDependency to a hidden Feature
description: A Feature cannot have an cross-scope ActivationDependency to a hidden Feature. For example, a Web site-scoped feature cannot be dependent on a site collection–scoped Feature that is not visible in the user interface.

details.resolution: Remove the ActivationDependency or make the target Feature visible. MSDN: 'Feature activation dependencies are not supported across scopes if the Feature that is depended upon is not visible. In other words, a Web site-scoped feature cannot be dependent on a site collection–scoped Feature that is not visible in the user interface.'
details.remarks: Remove the ActivationDependency or make the target Feature visible. MSDN: 'Feature activation dependencies are not supported across scopes if the Feature that is depended upon is not visible. In other words, a Web site-scoped feature cannot be dependent on a site collection–scoped Feature that is not visible in the user interface.'

message: Do not chain ActivationDependencies of Features when last Feature is visible
description: ActivationDependencies can work only one level deep. SharePoint Foundation does not support more than one level in activation dependencies if the last Feature is visible.

details.resolution: Remove the ActivationDependency or make the last Feature in the chain hidden. MSDN: 'SharePoint Foundation does not support more than one level in activation dependencies if the last Feature is visible—that is if a visible Feature depends on a second visible Feature that in turn depends on a third visible Feature. However, SharePoint Foundation does support more than one level in activation dependencies if a visible Feature depends on a second visible Feature that in turn depends on a hidden Feature.'
details.remarks: Remove the ActivationDependency or make the last Feature in the chain hidden. MSDN: 'SharePoint Foundation does not support more than one level in activation dependencies if the last Feature is visible—that is if a visible Feature depends on a second visible Feature that in turn depends on a third visible Feature. However, SharePoint Foundation does support more than one level in activation dependencies if a visible Feature depends on a second visible Feature that in turn depends on a hidden Feature.'

description: ActivationDependencies between Features can result in a circular dependency which is not allowed.

details.resolution: Ensure that the chain of ActivationDependencies does not result in a circle.
details.remarks: Ensure that the chain of ActivationDependencies does not result in a circle.

message: Remove spaces from resource keys
description: If attributes in SharePoint elements are localized with resources the resource key cannot contains spaces.

details.resolution: If attributes in SharePoint elements are localized with resources the resource key must be defined with the following pattern: $Resources:BaseFileName,ResourceName The dollar sign ($) indicates that an expression follows. The prefix 'Resources' indicates the type of expression. The suffix after the colon (:) is the expression value to resolve. The first part of the value is the base file name for a resource file. The part that follows the comma is the name of the localized string to retrieve from the file. No spaces are allowed anywhere in the expression. Note: You might see resource expressions that end with a semicolon (;). This delimiter is acceptable but is not required by SharePoint Foundation 2010.
details.remarks: If attributes in SharePoint elements are localized with resources the resource key must be defined with the following pattern: $Resources:BaseFileName,ResourceName The dollar sign ($) indicates that an expression follows. The prefix 'Resources' indicates the type of expression. The suffix after the colon (:) is the expression value to resolve. The first part of the value is the base file name for a resource file. The part that follows the comma is the name of the localized string to retrieve from the file. No spaces are allowed anywhere in the expression. Note: You might see resource expressions that end with a semicolon (;). This delimiter is acceptable but is not required by SharePoint Foundation 2010.

message: Add translation for a resource key
description: If attributes in SharePoint elements are localized with resources the resource key must be available in a resx file.

details.resolution: There could be several reasons why the translation for the resource key could not be found: - The resource file (.resx) is has not been created by the developer - The resource file has been created but the WSP with the resource file is not part of the current analysis - The resource file is available and part of the analysis, but the resource key is not present in the resource file Depending on the reason for the error add a file with extension .resx to the solution and ensure that the resource key is present in the resx file. Follow the instructions on MSDN to localize SharePoint solutions (see links below).
details.remarks: There could be several reasons why the translation for the resource key could not be found: - The resource file (.resx) is has not been created by the developer - The resource file has been created but the WSP with the resource file is not part of the current analysis - The resource file is available and part of the analysis, but the resource key is not present in the resource file Depending on the reason for the error add a file with extension .resx to the solution and ensure that the resource key is present in the resx file. Follow the instructions on MSDN to localize SharePoint solutions (see links below).

message: Do not use inline code in ASPX pages
description: ASPX pages should not contain inline code. Use code behind instead.

details.resolution: Remove the inline code and use code behind instead. MSDN: Because inline code can run with full trust on the server, it is possible for a developer to expose data from anywhere in the SharePoint environment by making a call to elevate the privileges of the code during run time. As a best practice, any inline code should therefore be reviewed for security implications before it is allowed to be installed and run on the server.

MSDN: Because inline code can run with full trust on the server, it is possible for a developer to expose data from anywhere in the SharePoint environment by making a call to elevate the privileges of the code during run time. description: It is not allowed to read or write directly to SharePoint databases. Use API, webservices etc. instead.

details.resolution: Remove the statement for reading from the SharePoint database (see Remarks for limitations of this rule). Microsoft Statement regarding read operations of SharePoint database: Reading from the SharePoint databases programmatically, or manually, can cause unexpected locking within Microsoft SQL Server which can adversely affect performance. Any read operations against the SharePoint databases that originate from queries, scripts, .dll files (and so on) that are not provided by the Microsoft SharePoint Development Team or by Microsoft SharePoint Support will be considered unsupported if they are identified as a barrier to the resolution of a Microsoft support engagement. If unsupported read operations are identified as a barrier to the resolution of support engagement, the database will be considered to be in an unsupported state. To return the database to a supported state, all unsupported read activities must stop
details.remarks: Remove the statement for reading from the SharePoint database (see Remarks for limitations of this rule). Microsoft Statement regarding read operations of SharePoint database: Reading from the SharePoint databases programmatically, or manually, can cause unexpected locking within Microsoft SQL Server which can adversely affect performance. Any read operations against the SharePoint databases that originate from queries, scripts, .dll files (and so on) that are not provided by the Microsoft SharePoint Development Team or by Microsoft SharePoint Support will be considered unsupported if they are identified as a barrier to the resolution of a Microsoft support engagement. If unsupported read operations are identified as a barrier to the resolution of support engagement, the database will be considered to be in an unsupported state. To return the database to a supported state, all unsupported read activities must stop

message: Declare attribute 'Title' and 'Description' in Solutions
description: To make it easier to identify Solutions in the Solution Gallery in SharePoint the attributes 'Title' and 'Description' should be declared.

details.resolution: A Solution should contain a title and a description to describe the purpose of the solution.
details.remarks: A Solution should contain a title and a description to describe the purpose of the solution.

message: Define AssemblyFileVersion in Assembly
description: In SharePoint changing the AssemblyVersion very frequently can lead to problems, because the full name of the assembly could be used in features or webparts. However, to identify the version of the assembly the attribute 'AssemblyFileVersion' should be used (used with same major version but incremented minor version, build etc.)

details.resolution: The Assembly should define attribute 'AssemblyFileVersion' to communicate the lastest release of the assembly.
details.remarks: The Assembly should define attribute 'AssemblyFileVersion' to communicate the lastest release of the assembly.

message: Do not store Urls hardcoded in Assembly
description: Remove hard coded Urls from the code and make them configurable.

details.resolution: Remove the string from the code and make it configurable e.g. via PropertyBag or a SharePoint list.
details.remarks: Remove the string from the code and make it configurable e.g. via PropertyBag or a SharePoint list.

message: Do not create ContentTypes in code
description: ContentTypes should be created declaratively in XML and not in code.

details.resolution: Create ContentType via XML files in a Feature.
details.remarks: Create ContentType via XML files in a Feature.

message: Do not inherit WebParts from Microsoft.SharePoint.WebPartPages.WebPart
description: WebParts should be inherited from the ASP.NET Webpart (System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart). Do not inherit from the SharePoint WebPart.

details.resolution: Inherit the WebPart from System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart. This is the recommended way. MSDN states: When creating new Web Parts, you have the option of creating Web Parts that inherit from System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart (recommended) or Microsoft.SharePoint.WebPartPages.WebPart. The SharePoint FoundationWebPart class exists primarily for the purpose of backward compatibility and to provide a small set of features that are not available in the System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart class.
details.remarks: Inherit the WebPart from System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart. This is the recommended way. MSDN states: When creating new Web Parts, you have the option of creating Web Parts that inherit from System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart (recommended) or Microsoft.SharePoint.WebPartPages.WebPart. The SharePoint FoundationWebPart class exists primarily for the purpose of backward compatibility and to provide a small set of features that are not available in the System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart class.

message: Do not make SiteDefinition visible in the whole farm
description: Site definitions are visible in the whole farm by default. The attribute 'VisibilityFeatureDependency' provides a way to hide the site definition depending on an activated feature.

details.resolution: Configurations in a SiteDefinition should not be visible in the whole farm. Use attribute 'VisibilityFeatureDependency' to hide the site template depending on activated features.
details.remarks: Configurations in a SiteDefinition should not be visible in the whole farm. Use attribute 'VisibilityFeatureDependency' to hide the site template depending on activated features.

message: Declare attribute 'Description' in Features
description: A Feature should contain a description of the purpose of a Feature in attribute 'Description'.

details.resolution: A Feature should contain a description.
details.remarks: A Feature should contain a description.

message: Declare attribute 'Version' in Features
description: A feature should contain a valid version number in attribute 'Version'. This may be necessary to use FeatureUpgrade method to allow updates in the future.

details.resolution: A feature should contain a version.
details.remarks: A feature should contain a version.

message: Make Features with scope 'Farm' or 'WebApplication' visible
description: Feature of scope 'Farm' or 'WebApplication' should not be hidden. They are not visible for the farm administrator in the Central Administration and cannot be deactivated via the UI e.g. in case of problems. If the feature is visible in the Central Administration the farm administrator can easier identify available and activated features.

details.resolution: A Feature with scope 'Farm' or 'WebApplication' should set 'Hidden="FALSE"' to make the feature visible in Central Administration and allow the deactivation by the farm administrator in case of problems.
details.remarks: A Feature with scope 'Farm' or 'WebApplication' should set 'Hidden="FALSE"' to make the feature visible in Central Administration and allow the deactivation by the farm administrator in case of problems.

message: Consider to make Feature with scope 'Web' or 'Site' hidden
description: Consider to make Features with scope 'Web' or 'Site' hidden to avoid activation via the UI.

details.resolution: A Feature with scope 'Web' or 'Site' should be set 'Hidden="TRUE"'. In a shared environment features should be set to hidden unless activation through the web frontend is required in all site collections where the solution is deployed.
details.remarks: A Feature with scope 'Web' or 'Site' should be set 'Hidden="TRUE"'. In a shared environment features should be set to hidden unless activation through the web frontend is required in all site collections where the solution is deployed.

message: Declare attribute 'Title' and 'Description' in FeatureActivitationDependencies
description: To make it easier to identify feature activation dependencies the attributes title and description should contain the title and description of the referenced feature.

details.resolution: A FeatureActivationDependency should contain the title and the desccription of the referenced target feature.
details.remarks: A FeatureActivationDependency should contain the title and the desccription of the referenced target feature.

message: Define attribute 'ReceiverAssembly' in Feature as full qualified assembly name
description: If a Feature references an Assembly in attribute 'ReceiverAssembly' the given value should be a full qualified assembly name (e.g. 'System.Data, Version=1.0.3300.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=b77a5c561934e089'). Although the order of the values in the assembly name is not mandatory a well-formed assembly name improves readability of the XML code.

details.resolution: Change attribute 'ReceiverAssembly' in a Feature to a full qualified assembly name.
details.remarks: Change attribute 'ReceiverAssembly' in a Feature to a full qualified assembly name.

message: Declare all FieldTypes in a single file
description: If multiple FieldTypes are deployed by a Solution these FieldTypes should be store in a single XML file to avoid unnecessary files.

details.resolution: Move all FieldTypes into a single file and remove unnecessary files.
details.remarks: Move all FieldTypes into a single file and remove unnecessary files.

message: Declare attribute 'Inherits' in ContentTypes
description: In SharePoint 2010 the new attribute 'Inherits' for ContentTypes defines whether fields of the parent ContentType are inherited to the ContentType. For compatibility reasons to SharePoint 2007 this attribute should be specified.

details.resolution: A ContentType should specify attribute 'Inherits' for compatibility reasons.
details.remarks: A ContentType should specify attribute 'Inherits' for compatibility reasons.

message: Define attribute 'ID' in ContentTypes uppercase
description: The ID of a ContentType should by a GUID in uppercase letters to avoid problems when accessing ContentTypes in code.

details.resolution: Make attribute 'Id' in ContentType uppercase.
details.remarks: Make attribute 'Id' in ContentType uppercase.

message: Declare 'TemplateType' and 'FeatureId' for external ListInstance
description: If the ListInstance seems to be used for an external list, the correct TemplateType (600) should be used.

details.resolution: Add corrent values for attributes TemplateType and FeatureId to ListInstance.
details.remarks: Add corrent values for attributes TemplateType and FeatureId to ListInstance.

message: Declare attribute 'Description' in CustomActionGroup
description: CustomActionGroup should define attribute Description.

details.resolution: A CustomActionGroup should define the attribute 'Description'. Although the attribute is optional, it should specify a longer description that is exposed as a sub-description for the action group.
details.remarks: A CustomActionGroup should define the attribute 'Description'. Although the attribute is optional, it should specify a longer description that is exposed as a sub-description for the action group.

message: Declare attribute 'Sequence' in DelegateControl.
description: Attribute 'Sequence' should be declared to specify the sequence number for the control, which determines whether the control is added to the control tree for a page. The control with the lowest sequence number is added to the tree.

details.resolution: Add attribute 'Sequence' to DelegateControl. See sample below: <Elements xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/sharepoint/"> <Control Id="AdditionalPageHead" Sequence="1000" ControlAssembly="EcmaScriptDelegate, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=publickeytoken" ControlClass="EcmaScriptDelegate.EcmaScriptDelegateControl"> </Elements>
details.remarks: Add attribute 'Sequence' to DelegateControl. See sample below: <Elements xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/sharepoint/"> <Control Id="AdditionalPageHead" Sequence="1000" ControlAssembly="EcmaScriptDelegate, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=publickeytoken" ControlClass="EcmaScriptDelegate.EcmaScriptDelegateControl"> </Elements>

message: Declare attribute 'Id' in DelegateControl.
description: Attribute 'Id' should be declared. Otherwise the delegate control will never be added to a control container.

details.resolution: Add attribute 'Id' to DelegateControl. See sample below: <Elements xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/sharepoint/"> <Control Id="AdditionalPageHead" Sequence="1000" ControlAssembly="EcmaScriptDelegate, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=publickeytoken" ControlClass="EcmaScriptDelegate.EcmaScriptDelegateControl"> </Elements>
details.remarks: Add attribute 'Id' to DelegateControl. See sample below: <Elements xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/sharepoint/"> <Control Id="AdditionalPageHead" Sequence="1000" ControlAssembly="EcmaScriptDelegate, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=publickeytoken" ControlClass="EcmaScriptDelegate.EcmaScriptDelegateControl"> </Elements>

message: Declare property 'Title' and 'Description' in WebPart
description: A WebPart should contain the attribute title and description to provide meaningfull information to the end user which would add the web part to a page.

details.resolution: The Webpart should have property title and description in the .webpart file. See sample below:
details.remarks: The Webpart should have property title and description in the .webpart file. See sample below:

message: Do not write in ASPX Pages 'Register' tags in a single line
description: ASPX pages should write the Register tag in separate lines to improve readability of the code.

details.resolution: The ASPX page should write Register tag in separate lines to improve readability of the code.
details.remarks: The ASPX page should write Register tag in separate lines to improve readability of the code.

message: Avoid inline JavaScript in ASPX Pages
description: ASPX pages should not contain JavaScript code. Use separate .JS files instead.

details.resolution: Move the JavaScript code to a separate .JS file.
details.remarks: Move the JavaScript code to a separate .JS file.

message: Avoid inline CSS in ASPX Pages
description: ASPX pages should not contain CSS code. Use separate .CSS files instead.

details.resolution: Move the CSS code to a separate .CSS file.
details.remarks: Move the CSS code to a separate .CSS file.

message: Do not use spaces in file or folders names
description: Files should be stored in subfolders which are named after the solution, or start with the solution. Avoid using dots or spaces in pathnames.

details.resolution: Remove the spaces from file names or folder names. This may lead to problems with some functions in SharePoint.
details.remarks: Remove the spaces from file names or folder names. This may lead to problems with some functions in SharePoint.

message: Instantiate a new SPSite inside RunWithElevatedPrivileges
description: An SPSite object created outside the delegate can be referenced inside the delegate, however, the methods and property assessors of the object run with the privileges of the user context in which the objects were created, not with the elevated privileges.

details.resolution: Instantiate a new SPSite inside RunWithElevatedPrivileges. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Instantiate a new SPSite inside RunWithElevatedPrivileges. Bad Practice:

message: Do not call SPList.Items
description: Do not call SPList.Items. Use SPList.GetItems(SPQuery query) instead.

details.resolution: Use SPList.GetItems(SPQuery query) instead.
details.remarks: Use SPList.GetItems(SPQuery query) instead.

message: Do not call SPList.Items.GetItemById()
description: Do not call SPList.Items.GetItemById(). Use SPList.GetItemById instead.

details.resolution: Replace calls to SPList.Items.GetItemById() with SPList.GetItemById(). Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Replace calls to SPList.Items.GetItemById() with SPList.GetItemById(). Bad Practice:

message: Do not call SPList.Items[]
description: Do not call SPList.Items[int] or SPList.Items[Guid]. Use SPList.GetItemByUniqueId(Guid) or SPList.GetItemById(int) instead.

details.resolution: Replace calls to SPList.Items[] with SPList.GetItemById or SPList.GetItemByUniqueId. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Replace calls to SPList.Items[] with SPList.GetItemById or SPList.GetItemByUniqueId. Bad Practice:

message: Do not call SPList.Items.Count
description: Do not call SPList.Items.Count. Use SPList.ItemCount instead.

details.resolution: Replace calls to SPList.Items.Count with SPList.ItemCount. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Replace calls to SPList.Items.Count with SPList.ItemCount. Bad Practice:

message: Do not call SPListItemVersion.Delete to delete multiple versions
description: When you delete multiple versions of a list item, use the DeleteByID() method; do not use the Delete() method. You will experience performance problems if you delete each SPListItemVersion object from an SPListItemVersionCollection object.

details.resolution: The recommended practice is to create an array that contains the ID properties of each version and then delete each version by using the SPListItemVersionCollection.DeleteByID method.
details.remarks: The recommended practice is to create an array that contains the ID properties of each version and then delete each version by using the SPListItemVersionCollection.DeleteByID method.

message: Do not call SPFileVersion.Delete to delete multiple versions
description: When you delete multiple versions of a file, use the DeleteByID() method; do not use the Delete() method. You will experience performance problems if you delete each SPFileVersion object from an SPFileVersionVersionCollection object.

details.resolution: The recommended practice is to create an array that contains the ID properties of each version and then delete each version by using the SPFileVersionCollection.DeleteByID method.
details.remarks: The recommended practice is to create an array that contains the ID properties of each version and then delete each version by using the SPFileVersionCollection.DeleteByID method.

message: Do not enable ObjectTracking in Linq.DataContext
description: If your code only queries lists, rather than adding, deleting, or editing list items, then you can turn off object change tracking. Doing so will improve performance. Set the ObjectTrackingEnabled property to false.

details.resolution: Set the ObjectTrackingEnabled property to false.
details.remarks: Set the ObjectTrackingEnabled property to false.

message: Do not access SPListCollection by indexer multiple times
description: Do not access SPListCollection by indexer multiple times. Instantiates the list object only once and assigns it to a variable in order to set properties and call methods.

details.resolution: Instantiate the list object once and assigns it to a variable in order to set properties and call methods. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Instantiate the list object once and assigns it to a variable in order to set properties and call methods. Bad Practice:

message: Do not call SPFolder.Files.Count
description: Do not call SPFolder.Files.Count. Use SPFolder.ItemCount instead.

details.resolution: Replace calls to SPFolder.Files.Count with SPFolder.ItemCount. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Replace calls to SPFolder.Files.Count with SPFolder.ItemCount. Bad Practice:

message: Use SPBuiltInContentTypeId to reference builtin ContentType
description: Use SPBuiltInContentTypeId to reference builtin ContentType.

details.resolution: Replace strings which contain the ID of a SharePoint default ContentType with the SPBuiltInContentTypeId. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Replace strings which contain the ID of a SharePoint default ContentType with the SPBuiltInContentTypeId. Bad Practice:

message: Use SPBuiltInFieldId to reference builtin Field
description: Use SPBuiltInFieldId to reference builtin Field.

details.resolution: Do not reference SharePoint default Field in a string. Use SPBuiltInFieldId instead. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Do not reference SharePoint default Field in a string. Use SPBuiltInFieldId instead. Bad Practice:

description: Define RowLimit for SPQuery to limit the number of items returned in the query.

details.resolution: The RowLimit property is used together with the ListItemCollectionPosition property to define paging in a query. See sample below:
details.remarks: The RowLimit property is used together with the ListItemCollectionPosition property to define paging in a query. See sample below:

message: Avoid using AppSettings to store configuration values
description: Avoid storing or reading configuration values in web.config via AppSettings.

details.resolution: Remove usage of System.Configuration.ConfigurationSettings.AppSettings. Use property bags or SharePoint lists, or hierarchical object storage instead.
details.remarks: Remove usage of System.Configuration.ConfigurationSettings.AppSettings. Use property bags or SharePoint lists, or hierarchical object storage instead.

message: Apply lock when caching SharePoint objects
description: Some SharePoint objects are not thread safe and caching can cause applications to fail and cause unexpected or unrelated user errors. To avoid this ensure locking of cached objects.

details.resolution: Follow the instructions for locking the cache as described in 'Object Caching Techniques' (see link). Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Follow the instructions for locking the cache as described in 'Object Caching Techniques' (see link). Bad Practice:

message: Do not call SPItemEventProperties.OpenWeb()
description: Do not call SPItemEventProperties.OpenWeb(). Use the newly introduced SPItemEventProperties.Web property instead for better performance and to avoid the need to call Dispose().

details.resolution: Replace calls to SPItemEventProperties.OpenWeb() with SPItemEventProperties.Web property for better performance and to avoid the need to call Dispose(). Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Replace calls to SPItemEventProperties.OpenWeb() with SPItemEventProperties.Web property for better performance and to avoid the need to call Dispose(). Bad Practice:

message: Do not request SPField from SPFieldCollection by index. Use SPFieldCollection.GetField() instead.
description: Calling SPFieldCollection[] to retrieve a SPField in a web could fail if not the display name is used as argument. Better use SPWeb.Fields.GetField() which returns the field with the specified internal, display, or static name.

details.resolution: Replace calls to SPFieldCollection[] with SPFieldCollection.GetField(). SharePoint searches first by internal name; then, if necessary, by display name; finally, if necessary, by static name. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Replace calls to SPFieldCollection[] with SPFieldCollection.GetField(). SharePoint searches first by internal name; then, if necessary, by display name; finally, if necessary, by static name. Bad Practice:

message: Do not call SPWeb.GetListFromUrl. Use SPWeb.GetListFromWebPartPageUrl instead.
description: SPWeb.GetListFromUrl gets the list that is associated with the first Web Part on the specified Web Parts page. Beginning in Windows SharePoint Services 3.0, use the GetListFromWebPartPageUrl method instead of this method.

details.resolution: Replace calls to SPWeb.GetListFromUrl with SPWeb.GetListFromWebPartPageUrl. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Replace calls to SPWeb.GetListFromUrl with SPWeb.GetListFromWebPartPageUrl. Bad Practice:

message: Assign RowLimit for SPQuery in limited range
description: Assign RowLimit for SPQuery within the limited range (default 1 to 2000).

details.resolution: The RowLimit property is used together with the ListItemCollectionPosition property to define paging in a query. See sample below:
details.remarks: The RowLimit property is used together with the ListItemCollectionPosition property to define paging in a query. See sample below:

message: Do not activate or deactivate Features via API
description: Do not activate or deactivate Features in code via API. Consider using Powershell or Feature Stapling.

details.resolution: Remove calls to SPFeatureCollection.Add() and SPFeatureCollection.Remove() to activate or deactivate Features. Use PowerShell or Feature Stapling instead. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Remove calls to SPFeatureCollection.Add() and SPFeatureCollection.Remove() to activate or deactivate Features. Use PowerShell or Feature Stapling instead. Bad Practice:

message: Custom field types should not be user creatable
description: Custom field types should not be user creatable because in this case they are visible in the complete farm which may not be the intention.

details.resolution: Set the property 'UserCreatable' to 'FALSE' in a custom field type. In shared SharePoint environments custom field types should not be user creatable unless cration of fields through the web frontend is required in all site collections where the solution is deployed.
details.remarks: Set the property 'UserCreatable' to 'FALSE' in a custom field type. In shared SharePoint environments custom field types should not be user creatable unless cration of fields through the web frontend is required in all site collections where the solution is deployed.

message: Consider using SPContentTypeCollection.BestMatch(SPContentTypeId) to retrieve a Content Type
description: Use SPContentTypeCollection.BestMatch(string) to retrieve a Content Type from a SPContentTypeCollection.

details.resolution: Consider using SPContentTypeCollection.BestMatch() instead of using the indexer. See sample below: Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Consider using SPContentTypeCollection.BestMatch() instead of using the indexer. See sample below: Bad Practice:

message: Define Type of ListTemplate greater than 10000
description: The ListTemplate Type should be greater than 10000. This makes it easier to identify custom ListTemplates.

details.resolution: The Type of the ListTemplate should be greater than 10000. It helps to ensure that there is no misunderstanding with default ListTemplates.
details.remarks: The Type of the ListTemplate should be greater than 10000. It helps to ensure that there is no misunderstanding with default ListTemplates.

message: Do not instantiate SPList in Receiver
description: Do not instantiate an SPList object within an event receiver.

details.resolution: Do not instantiate an object of type 'Microsoft.SharePoint.SPList' in EventReceiver. Best practise is to get these objects from the current context.
details.remarks: Do not instantiate an object of type 'Microsoft.SharePoint.SPList' in EventReceiver. Best practise is to get these objects from the current context.

message: Do not instantiate SPListItem in Receiver
description: Do not instantiate an SPListItem object within an event receiver.

details.resolution: Do not instantiate an object of type 'Microsoft.SharePoint.SPListItem'. Best practise is to get these objects from the current context.
details.remarks: Do not instantiate an object of type 'Microsoft.SharePoint.SPListItem'. Best practise is to get these objects from the current context.

message: Do not instantiate SPSite in Receiver
description: Do not instantiate an SPSite object within an event receiver.

details.resolution: Do not instantiate an object of type 'Microsoft.SharePoint.SPSite'. Best practise is to get these objects from the current context. Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Do not instantiate an object of type 'Microsoft.SharePoint.SPSite'. Best practise is to get these objects from the current context. Bad Practice:

message: Do not instantiate SPWeb in Receiver
description: Do not instantiate an SPWeb object within an event receiver.

details.resolution: Do not instantiate an object of type 'Microsoft.SharePoint.SPWeb'. Best practise is to get these objects from the current context.
details.remarks: Do not instantiate an object of type 'Microsoft.SharePoint.SPWeb'. Best practise is to get these objects from the current context.

message: Consider the deployment of solution per web application and not globally
description: Solution should not be deployed globally to reduce the impact of the solution for the SharePoint farm. Add either SafeControls, DWPFiles, CASPolicies or ApplicationResourceFiles to ensure that the solution is deployed to a dedicated web application.

details.resolution: Solution should not be deployed globally to reduce the impact of the solution for the SharePoint farm. Add either SafeControls, DWPFiles, CASPolicies or ApplicationResourceFiles to ensure that the solution is deployed to a dedicated web application.
details.remarks: Solution should not be deployed globally to reduce the impact of the solution for the SharePoint farm. Add either SafeControls, DWPFiles, CASPolicies or ApplicationResourceFiles to ensure that the solution is deployed to a dedicated web application.

message: Do not deploy prohibited assemblies
description: In some case WSPBuilder includes prohibited assemblies into the package, e.g. 'ssocli.dll'.

details.resolution: Remove prohibited assemblies from the solution.
details.remarks: Remove prohibited assemblies from the solution.

message: Do not deploy thumbs.db
description: In some case the file thumbs.db is generated in a Visual Studio project. This file should not be included in the WSP package.

details.resolution: Remove files with name 'thumbs.db' from a Solution.
details.remarks: Remove files with name 'thumbs.db' from a Solution.

message: Do not reset webserver
description: A solution should not reset the webserver.

details.resolution: A Solution may reset the webserver during deployment on the farm. This should be avoided by setting the attribute 'ResetWebServer' to FALSE.
details.remarks: A Solution may reset the webserver during deployment on the farm. This should be avoided by setting the attribute 'ResetWebServer' to FALSE.

message: Define mode 'Recycle' for Solution upgrade
description: To reduce the downtime of a SharePoint farm during deployment the solution should not use default setting 'StartStop' for upgrading solutions. Spedifying 'Recycle' only recycles affected application pools and will not stop them.

details.resolution: Define value 'Recycle' in attribute 'ResetWebServerModeOnUpgrade' for upgrades of the Solution.
details.remarks: Define value 'Recycle' in attribute 'ResetWebServerModeOnUpgrade' for upgrades of the Solution.

message: Do not deploy files directly into system folder
description: Solutions should not write in folders of system files directly. If you need to deploy a file in a system folder, use a project specific subfolder.

details.resolution: Deploy files only into a custom subfolder (named after the solution name). This helps to prevent conflicts with deployed files from other solutions.
details.remarks: Deploy files only into a custom subfolder (named after the solution name). This helps to prevent conflicts with deployed files from other solutions.

message: Do not deploy batch files (.bat)
description: Batch files should not be included in the WSP package.

details.resolution: Remove batch files from the Solution.
details.remarks: Remove batch files from the Solution.

message: Do not deploy PowerShell scripts (.ps1)
description: PowerShell scripts should not be included in the WSP package.

details.resolution: Remove PowerShell files from the Solution.
details.remarks: Remove PowerShell files from the Solution.

message: Do not deploy setups (.msi)
description: Setups like .msi files should not be included in the WSP package.

details.resolution: Remove setup files from the Solution.
details.remarks: Remove setup files from the Solution.

message: Deploy Assembly which must run in full trust to GAC
description: The Assembly must be deployed to global assembly cache because it contains code which must be run in full trust or must be avaible to other components or services.

details.resolution: Assembly which contains feature receiver or any other code which needs to run under full trust to GAC.
details.remarks: Assembly which contains feature receiver or any other code which needs to run under full trust to GAC.

message: Avoid deployment of Assembly to GAC if it is not necessary
description: Assemblies should only be deployed to global assembly cache (GAC) if they contain e.g. feature receivers, event receivers, timer jobs or workflows. Consider the deployment to WebApplication.

details.resolution: Change DeploymentTarget in manifest.xml for the assembly to 'WebApplication'.
details.remarks: Change DeploymentTarget in manifest.xml for the assembly to 'WebApplication'.

message: Do not deploy assembly with DEBUG mode
description: Assembly should be build with RELEASE mode. Main reason is to prevent running code which is defined within #DEBUG preprocessor directive and which typically should not run in productive environments.

details.resolution: The assembly should be build with RELEASE mode to avoid performance and security issues with assemblies in DEBUG mode.
details.remarks: The assembly should be build with RELEASE mode to avoid performance and security issues with assemblies in DEBUG mode.

message: Do not deploy SharePoint assemblies
description: In some case Visual Studio or WSPBuilder include SharePoint assemblies into the package (e.g. Microsoft.Search.dll). This is not allowed.

details.resolution: Remove the SharePoint assembly from the solution package.
details.remarks: Remove the SharePoint assembly from the solution package.

message: Do not deploy assembly multiple times
description: In some case the same assembly is included in several WSP packages of the same solution. This can occur if Visual Studio or WSPBuilder includes the files automatically into the WSP package.

details.resolution: The assembly should not be deployed multiple times.
details.remarks: The assembly should not be deployed multiple times.

message: Do not deploy empty Assemblies
description: Assemblies without custom classes should not be deployed to SharePoint. This helps to reduce unneeded IISResets during deployment.

details.resolution: Remove empty Assembly from Solution. Sometimes it may be necessary to deploy an empty assembly. One reason could be to avoid a 'Globally' deployment of the Solution and enforce the deployment 'per Webapplication'. This can achieve by adding a 'SafeControl' to the manifest.xml. But this makes an assembly necessary which may be empty. Visual Studio automatically includes the assembly in WSP packages. To avoid this set property 'Include Assembly in Package' to FALSE.
details.remarks: Remove empty Assembly from Solution. Sometimes it may be necessary to deploy an empty assembly. One reason could be to avoid a 'Globally' deployment of the Solution and enforce the deployment 'per Webapplication'. This can achieve by adding a 'SafeControl' to the manifest.xml. But this makes an assembly necessary which may be empty. Visual Studio automatically includes the assembly in WSP packages. To avoid this set property 'Include Assembly in Package' to FALSE.

message: Do not deploy SPWebConfigModifications via features
description: Deployment of SPWebConfigModifications with a feature receiver should be avoided. The activation of this feature will start a timer job and will initiate the restart of services which may lead to problems during a deployment. Consider deploying of SPWebConfigModifications via PowerShell script or supplemental config file.

details.resolution: Avoid changes of web.config in features. Consider deploying them with PowerShell or supplemental config files.
details.remarks: Avoid changes of web.config in features. Consider deploying them with PowerShell or supplemental config files.

message: Do not deploy RootFile to TEMPLATE folder
description: Deploy a RootFile not to the TEMPLATE folder. Deploy this file as TemplateFile in the solution.

details.resolution: Change the RootFile to a TemplateFile in the manifest.xml of the solution.
details.remarks: Change the RootFile to a TemplateFile in the manifest.xml of the solution.

message: Do not deploy RootFile multiple times
description: Deploy a RootFile only once to SharePoint. Do not deploy the file by different solutions because this could lead to problems if one solution is retracted and removes the file.

details.resolution: Remove the RootFile from one of the solutions and deploy the file only once.
details.remarks: Remove the RootFile from one of the solutions and deploy the file only once.

message: Do not deploy Images to LAYOUTS folder
description: Do not deploy Images to LAYOUTS folder. Deploy to IMAGES folder instead.

details.resolution: Change the deployment location of the TemplateFile so that images (like .gif, .jpg, .png) are deployed to /TEMPLATES/IMAGES or a folder with locale id (/TEMPLATES/LAYOUTS/1033/IMAGES) and are available via URL '/_layouts/images/'.
details.remarks: Change the deployment location of the TemplateFile so that images (like .gif, .jpg, .png) are deployed to /TEMPLATES/IMAGES or a folder with locale id (/TEMPLATES/LAYOUTS/1033/IMAGES) and are available via URL '/_layouts/images/'.

message: Deploy only Images to IMAGES folder
description: Deploy only Images to IMAGES folder. For files which are not images choose a different folder (e.g. LAYOUTS).

details.resolution: Change the deployment location of the TemplateFile and do not deploy to /TEMPLATES/IMAGES.
details.remarks: Change the deployment location of the TemplateFile and do not deploy to /TEMPLATES/IMAGES.

message: Deploy binary files (like Assemblies) to ClientBin folder
description: Binary files should be deployed to LAYOUTS/ClientBin folder. This helps to find these files at the correct location.

details.resolution: Change the deployment location of the TemplateFile. Ensure that binary files like .dll, .xap are deployed to LAYOUTS/ClientBin folder.
details.remarks: Change the deployment location of the TemplateFile. Ensure that binary files like .dll, .xap are deployed to LAYOUTS/ClientBin folder.

message: Do not deploy TemplateFile multiple times
description: Deploy a TemplateFile only once to SharePoint. Do not deploy the file by different solutions because this could lead to problems if one solution is retracted and removes the file.

details.resolution: Remove the TemplateFile from one of the solutions and deploy the file only once.
details.remarks: Remove the TemplateFile from one of the solutions and deploy the file only once.

message: Do not deploy files of a Feature as TemplateFile
description: File which are deployed into the folder of a Feature should not be deployed as TemplateFile. Either deploy the files as ElementFiles in the Feature (preferred) or as Resources in manifest.xml.

details.resolution: Deploy the file as ElementFile in the feature.xml of the target Feature (edit feature.xml) or deploy the file as Resource (edit manifest.xml). See sample below: Bad Practice:
details.remarks: Deploy the file as ElementFile in the feature.xml of the target Feature (edit feature.xml) or deploy the file as Resource (edit manifest.xml). See sample below: Bad Practice:

message: Do not deploy Features ElementFiles as Resources
description: Resource files can be used to deploy resources to an existing Feature folder. If the target Feature is part of the same solution package binary files should be deployed as ElementFile in the Feature. If the target Feature is not part of the package it does make sense to use Resources (e.g. to deploy additional languages to existing features).

message: Localize property 'Title' and 'Description' in WebPart
description: Properties 'Title' and 'Description' in WebParts should be localized with .resx file.

details.resolution: The property 'Title' or 'Description' for a webpart are defined localized in the .webpart file as follows. <webParts> <webPart xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/WebPart/v3"> <metaData> <type name="TypeName, Version=VersionNumber, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=PublicKeyToken" /> <importErrorMessage>Cannot import this Web Part.</importErrorMessage> </metaData> <data> <properties> <property name="Title" type="string">$Resources:Wingtip.WebParts,WebPartTitle</property> <property name="Description" type="string">$Resources:Wingtip.WebParts,WebPartDesc</property> </properties> </data> </webPart> </webParts>
details.remarks: The property 'Title' or 'Description' for a webpart are defined localized in the .webpart file as follows. <webParts> <webPart xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/WebPart/v3"> <metaData> <type name="TypeName, Version=VersionNumber, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=PublicKeyToken" /> <importErrorMessage>Cannot import this Web Part.</importErrorMessage> </metaData> <data> <properties> <property name="Title" type="string">$Resources:Wingtip.WebParts,WebPartTitle</property> <property name="Description" type="string">$Resources:Wingtip.WebParts,WebPartDesc</property> </properties> </data> </webPart> </webParts>

message: Define Solution name as valid namespace
description: To make it easier to identify the correct wsp solution in the solution store the name of the solution should be a valid namespace (e.g. 'Company.Project.Components.wsp').

details.resolution: The name of the solution file should be a valid namespace (e.g. 'Company.ProjectName.Version.wsp').
details.remarks: The name of the solution file should be a valid namespace (e.g. 'Company.ProjectName.Version.wsp').

message: Files or Folders should contain the name of the parent solution
description: Files or their folders should be named after the solution. This helps do make the file location unique to prevent overwriting of existing files and it is easier to see which WSP solution deployed the file. The rule is case sensitive.

details.resolution: Change the name or location of the file. Use a subfolder which is named as the solution or start the filename with the solution name to increase maintainability. Replace "." with "_" in folder names. Examples: '{4}' or '{5}'
details.remarks: Change the name or location of the file. Use a subfolder which is named as the solution or start the filename with the solution name to increase maintainability. Replace "." with "_" in folder names. Examples: '{4}' or '{5}'

message: Solution name should start with company name
description: The solution name should start with company name to follow the rule 'CompanyName.ApplicationName.ComponentName.wsp'.

details.resolution: The name of the solution file should start with the company name.
details.remarks: The name of the solution file should start with the company name.

message: WebTemplate file in site definitions should start with 'WEBTEMP'
description: The name of the WebTemplate files should start with 'WEBTEMP'.

details.resolution: Rename the webtemp file and add 'WEBTEMP' at the beginning.
details.remarks: Rename the webtemp file and add 'WEBTEMP' at the beginning.

message: Feature name should start with solution name
description: A feature name should be prefixed with the name of the parent solution. This helps to make the feature name unique and it is easier to see which WSP solution deployed the feature. The rule is case sensitive.

details.resolution: Change the folder name of the Fature and add the solution name at the beginning, e.g. 'Company.Intranet.Components_ContentTypesFeature'.
details.remarks: Change the folder name of the Fature and add the solution name at the beginning, e.g. 'Company.Intranet.Components_ContentTypesFeature'.

message: Declare FieldType in File 'fldtypes_[namespace].xml'
description: The XML file which contains FieldTypes should follow the pattern 'fldtypes_[Namespace].xml'. [Namespace] represents the name of the WSP solution with replaced '.' with underscore. Reason: All FieldTypes are deployed to folder /SharePointRoot/Templates/XML and therefore must be stored in a file with a unique filename to avoid overriding existing FieldTypes from SharePoint or other custom solutions.

details.resolution: Rename the file according to the pattern 'fldtypes_[Namespace].xml'. If multiple files with FieldTypes are deployed the pattner is 'fldtypes_[Namespace]_[FieldName].xml'
details.remarks: Rename the file according to the pattern 'fldtypes_[Namespace].xml'. If multiple files with FieldTypes are deployed the pattner is 'fldtypes_[Namespace]_[FieldName].xml'

message: Do not use inline code in ASPX pages
description: ASPX pages should not contain inline code.

details.resolution: Remove the inline code and use code behind instead. MSDN: Because inline code can run with full trust on the server, it is possible for a developer to expose data from anywhere in the SharePoint environment by making a call to elevate the privileges of the code during run time. As a best practice, any inline code should therefore be reviewed for security implications before it is allowed to be installed and run on the server.
details.remarks: Remove the inline code and use code behind instead. MSDN: Because inline code can run with full trust on the server, it is possible for a developer to expose data from anywhere in the SharePoint environment by making a call to elevate the privileges of the code during run time. As a best practice, any inline code should therefore be reviewed for security implications before it is allowed to be installed and run on the server.

Add the following code to the Assembly.cs [assembly: AssemblyVersion("1.0.0.0")] // The AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute requires the assembly to be signed with a strong name key. [assembly:AllowPartiallyTrustedCallers]

message: Do not reference unavailable NET 3.5 assemblies
description: Code in the sandbox runs as a partially trusted caller. This means that such code can access only those .NET Framework 3.5 assemblies that have the AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute attribute.

details.resolution: Remove references to assemblies which do not have the AllowPartiallyTrustedCallers attribute.
details.remarks: Remove references to assemblies which do not have the AllowPartiallyTrustedCallers attribute.

message: Do not use unallowed SharePoint classes
description: Only a subset of the APIs in Microsoft.SharePoint.dll are available in sandboxed solutions.

details.resolution: Remove the calls to unavailable SharePoint classes.
details.remarks: Remove the calls to unavailable SharePoint classes.

message: Do not inherit WebParts from SharePoint WebPart
description: Sandboxed solutions can include only Web Parts derived from the ASP.NET class.

details.resolution: Inherit the WebPart from System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.
details.remarks: Inherit the WebPart from System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart.

message: Do not reference assemblies without AllowPartiallyTrustedCallers attribute
description: Code in the sandboxed worker process can call only assemblies that have the AllowPartiallyTrustedCallersAttribute. This means that most custom assemblies that you deploy in sandboxed solutions must have this attribute.

details.resolution: Remove references to assemblies which do not have the AllowPartiallyTrustedCallers attribute.
details.remarks: Remove references to assemblies which do not have the AllowPartiallyTrustedCallers attribute.

message: Do not create static fields and properties
description: Avoid creating static fields and properties in your sandboxed code.

details.resolution: When a specific sandboxed solution is handled for the first time on a given server that is running the SharePoint Foundation Sandboxed Code Service (sometimes called the User Code Host Service), the service creates an application domain for it in a sandboxed worker process, and all static variables in the solution code are loaded into the domain. The application domain stays alive after the sandboxed solution finishes and is reused if that same sandboxed solution is requested again, perhaps by a different user on a different site collection. A side effect of this system is that the static values are not reloaded, and these values are not necessarily appropriate to every execution of the sandboxed solution in every context. For example, suppose the solution code puts SPContext.Current into a static field named myContext. If the same solution is requested from another site collection, the value of myContext.Site is incorrect.
details.remarks: When a specific sandboxed solution is handled for the first time on a given server that is running the SharePoint Foundation Sandboxed Code Service (sometimes called the User Code Host Service), the service creates an application domain for it in a sandboxed worker process, and all static variables in the solution code are loaded into the domain. The application domain stays alive after the sandboxed solution finishes and is reused if that same sandboxed solution is requested again, perhaps by a different user on a different site collection. A side effect of this system is that the static values are not reloaded, and these values are not necessarily appropriate to every execution of the sandboxed solution in every context. For example, suppose the solution code puts SPContext.Current into a static field named myContext. If the same solution is requested from another site collection, the value of myContext.Site is incorrect.

details.resolution: Ensure that the passed parameters resolves to the current site collection.
details.remarks: Ensure that the passed parameters resolves to the current site collection.

details.remarks: Remove the call to the read-only property.

details.remarks: Although you can add new custom action in a sandboxed solution, you cannot create a new action group for your custom actions.

message: Do not deploy HideCustomAction

details.resolution: You cannot use a sandboxed solution to hide a menu item, ribbon button, or link on an administration page, such as the Site Settings page. However, you can add a new custom action to any of these with a sandboxed solution.
details.remarks: You cannot use a sandboxed solution to hide a menu item, ribbon button, or link on an administration page, such as the Site Settings page. However, you can add a new custom action to any of these with a sandboxed solution.

message: Do not dispose SPSite.RootWeb
description: An earlier version of the documentation indicated that the calling application should dispose of the SPSite.RootWeb property just before disposing of the SPSite object that is using it. This is no longer the official guidance. The dispose cleanup is handled automatically by the SharePoint framework.

details.resolution: Do not call Dispose on SPSite.RootWeb. MSDN: An earlier version indicated that the calling application should dispose of the SPSite.RootWeb property just before disposing of the SPSite object that is using it. This is no longer the official guidance. The dispose cleanup is handled automatically by the SharePoint framework. Additionally, SPSite properties LockIssue, Owner, and SecondaryContact used the RootWeb property internally. Given the updated guidance for RootWeb, it is no longer advisable to call the Dispose method on the SPSite.RootWeb property whenever any of these properties are used.
details.remarks: Do not call Dispose on SPSite.RootWeb. This is no longer the official guidance. The dispose cleanup is handled automatically by the SharePoint framework. Given the updated guidance for RootWeb, it is no longer advisable to call the Dispose method on the SPSite.RootWeb property whenever any of these properties are used.

message: Do not dispose SPSite returned by SPControl.GetContextSite
description: If SPSite is obtained from the SharePoint context objects (GetContextSite method), the calling application should not call the Dispose method on the object.

details.resolution: If the SPSite object is obtained from the SharePoint context objects (GetContextSite method), the calling application should not call the Dispose method on the object. Doing so may cause the SharePoint object model to behave unpredictably or fail. This is due to an internal list that is kept in the SPSite and SPWeb objects derived in this way. Internally, the object model enumerates over this list after page completion to dispose of the objects properly. See sample from MSDN: Bad Coding Practice
details.remarks: If the SPSite object is obtained from the SharePoint context objects (GetContextSite method), the calling application should not call the Dispose method on the object. message: Do not define TemplateAssociation to template 'Document Workspace'
description: The site template for 'Document Workspace' (STS#2) is not available in SP 2013.

details.resolution: The Feature cannot deploy a TemplateAssociation to site template 'Document Workspace' (STS#2). The scenario of collaborating on a document is now provided by the Team Site site template.
details.remarks: The Feature cannot deploy a TemplateAssociation to site template 'Document Workspace' (STS#2). The scenario of collaborating on a document is now provided by the Team Site site template.

message: Do not define TemplateAssociation to templates for 'Meeting Workspace'
description: The site templates for 'Meeting Workspace' (MPS#*) is not available in SP 2013. This includes the Basic Meeting Workspace, Blank Meeting Workspace, Decision Meeting Workspace, Social Meeting Workspace, and Multipage Meeting Workspace.

details.resolution: The Feature cannot deploy a TemplateAssociation to site template 'Meeting Workspaces' (MPS#0, MPS#1, MPS#2, MPS#3, MPS#4). SharePoint 2013 and Office 2013 provide other features that support meetings and collaboration. The Meeting Workspace site templates will be removed completely from the next major release of SharePoint and sites that were created by using the Meeting Workspace site templates will not be supported.
details.remarks: The Feature cannot deploy a TemplateAssociation to site template 'Meeting Workspaces' (MPS#0, MPS#1, MPS#2, MPS#3, MPS#4). SharePoint 2013 and Office 2013 provide other features that support meetings and collaboration. The Meeting Workspace site templates will be removed completely from the next major release of SharePoint and sites that were created by using the Meeting Workspace site templates will not be supported.

message: Do not define TemplateAssociation to template 'Personalization Site'
description: The site template for 'Personalization Site' (SPSMSITE#0) is not available in SP 2013.

details.resolution: The Feature cannot deploy a TemplateAssociation to site template 'Personalization Site' (SPSMSITE#0). The Personalization Site site template was not a widely used site template. The Personalization Site site template was removed from SharePoint 2013 to simplify the list of templates that are available when a user creates a new site collection.
details.remarks: The Feature cannot deploy a TemplateAssociation to site template 'Personalization Site' (SPSMSITE#0). The Personalization Site site template was not a widely used site template. The Personalization Site site template was removed from SharePoint 2013 to simplify the list of templates that are available when a user creates a new site collection.

The Group Work site template was removed from SharePoint 2013 to simplify the list of templates that are available when a user creates a new site collection.
details.remarks: The Feature cannot deploy a TemplateAssociation to site template 'Group Work' (SGS#0, SGS#1). The Group Work site template was not a widely used site template.
